[[/r 1d8]] slashing - versatile ([[/r 1d10]])

Angry Mob Starter Pack (Uncommon).description:
Wondrous item, uncommon

With safety pitchforks and protest signs strapped to the back, this plain leather satchel's unassuming exterior hides a secret within: it houses an illusory mob.

Assemble the Mob! When you open this satchel as an action, you can designate up to four willing creatures you can see within 30 feet of you to be 'multiplied' for 1 hour. Each affected creature sprouts nine illusory duplicates that all have minor alterations: different clothes, hair, and heights. The duplicates surround and follow the original and seem completely real, including sounds, smells, and temperature appropriate to the creature depicted. So long as you and any multiplied creatures remain within 100 feet of the satchel, these duplicates muddle about, shouting vaguely angry phrases such as "Get them!", "Begone!", and "Why is existence vacuous and happiness illusory!?" If a duplicated creature is ever more than 100 feet away from a satchel, its duplicates vanish.

A creature that uses its action to examine the mob can determine that it is an illusion with a successful DC 13 Intelligence (Investigation) check, ascertaining which members of the mob are real creatures.

If a creature targets a member of the mob with an attack, roll a [[/r d10]]. On a 10, it hits a real creature within the mob (GM's choice). On a 1-9, undefined. Once this property of the item has been used, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

Bone Marrow Bouillon (Very Rare).name: Bone Marrow Bouillon (Very Rare) Bone Marrow Bouillon (Very Rare)
Bone Marrow Bouillon (Very Rare).description:
Potion, very rare

Doctor Jake Kill advertises his proprietary blend of bull's pituitary and caffeine as a "sure fire way to lose friends and alienate people, especially if those people are a swarm of marauding goblins." Oddly enough, he seems more than a little keen to get rid of this particular concoction...

Inner Monster. Tied up in a protective claw is a philter of bubbling red liquid. You can use an action to drink this potion, filling you with a sense of rage and selfishness as your muscles inflate and your veins bulge. You turn into a brute, the physical and mental manifestation of your most evil and selfish thoughts, for 10 minutes, and undergo the following changes:

  • Your size increases by one category and your weight is multiplied by eight.

  • You have advantage on Strength-based attack rolls, Strength checks, and Strength saving throws.

  • Your alignment changes to chaotic evil; you think of your own survival first and any trace of compassion or mercy is shredded.

  • You gain [[/r 2d6]] temporary hit points at the beginning of each of your turns.

  • Once for the duration of the serum, when you would be reduced to 0 hit points, you are instead reduced to 1 hit point.

When the effect ends, you return to normal and make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, you gain 1 level of exhaustion.

Glimmerbolt Hand Crossbow (Uncommon).name: Glimmerbolt Hand Crossbow (Uncommon) Glimmerbolt Hand Crossbow (Uncommon)
Glimmerbolt Hand Crossbow (Uncommon).description:
Weapon, uncommon (requires attunement)

Martial weapon, ranged weapon 3 lb.
[[/r 1d6]] piercing - ammunition (30/120 ft.), light, loading

Another weapon from Sister Victoria's arsenal, this simple crossbow has been blessed by the gods. At your command, the slack string of the crossbow glows bright gold and snaps into its catch; a glimmering quarrel of brilliant, radiant energy coalesces in place.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. This weapon has 4 charges and regains [[/r 1d4]] expended charges daily at dawn.

Glimmerbolt. When you take the Attack action on your turn while holding this crossbow, you can speak its first command word, expending 1 charge and causing a piece of radiant ammunition to load into the crossbow. The next attack you make with the crossbow before the end of your turn deals radiant damage instead of piercing damage, and deals an extra [[/r 1d6]] radiant damage on a hit.

Lumoflare. As an action while holding this crossbow, you can speak its second command word and expend 3 charges to fire an especially bright bolt at a point within 60 feet of you, where it detonates. Each creature in a 20-foot radius must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or become blinded until the end of your next turn. After this flash, the light, now dimmer, hangs in the air for 1 minute, shedding bright light for 20 feet, and dim light for an additional 20 feet.

Range. A weapon that can be used to make a ranged attack has a range shown in parentheses after the ammunition or thrown property. The range lists two numbers. The first is the weapon's normal range in feet, and the second indicates the weapon's maximum range. When attacking a target beyond normal range, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. You can't attack a target beyond the weapon's long range.

Ammunition. You can use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack only if you have ammunition to fire from the weapon. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack. Loading a one-handed weapon requires a free hand. At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield.

If you use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a melee attack, you treat the weapon as an improvised weapon. A sling must be loaded to deal any damage when used in this way.

Light. A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

Loading. Because of the time required to load this weapon, you can fire only one piece of ammunition from it when you use an action, bonus action, or reaction to fire it, regardless of the number of attacks you can normally make.

Garlycanthrope.description:
Wondrous item, uncommon

Originally commissioned by an infamous vampire huntress, Dr. Francis N. Stein's garlycanthropes have proved themselves the 'must-have commodity of the season' for monster hunters everywhere. Their ability to detect undead and shapechangers has saved many potential victims from the jaws of a mimic, or from walking into a vampire's lair.

Animate Bulb. As a bonus action while holding this item, you can speak its command word. In response, this inanimate bulb of garlic becomes a creature that uses the @Compendium[larsene-ledger-treasures-and-trinkets.loot-tavern-09-victorian-horror-item.gWeUDoA1qTD7Czvc]{Garlycanthrope} stat block, sprouting little legs, eyes, and a panting muzzle. It is extremely friendly to you and your allies, but is skittish if any of them are undead or shapechangers. In combat, the garlycanthrope shares your initiative count, but it takes its turn immediately after yours. It can move and use its reaction on its own, but the only action it takes on its turn is the Dodge action, unless you take a bonus action on your turn to command it to take one of the actions in its stat block or the Dash, Disengage, Help, Hide, or Search action. After 1 hour, or if the garlycanthrope is reduced to 0 hit points, it becomes an inanimate bulb of garlic once more. Once this property of the item has been used, it can't be used again until the next dawn. Be careful not to eat it in the meantime!

Rain, arrows, or maces, this wand can deflect them all. Disguised as an oiled blue silk umbrella, as any gentleman might carry, this magical implement gives you a heightened sense of danger.

This wand has 12 charges and regains [[/r 1d6 + 6]] expended charges daily at dawn. While holding it, you have advantage on initiative rolls.

Reflect. When you are hit by an attack that you can see while holding the wand, you can use your reaction to open the umbrella and roll a [[/r d8]]. You expend charges equal to the result of the roll, or however many remain in the wand (whichever is lower), and gain a bonus to AC equal to the number of charges expended until the start of your next turn. If this results in the triggering attack missing you, the attack bounces back at the creature that made it using the original attack roll, potentially causing the attacker to hit itself.

Grave's Embrace. Trailing from your back, ragged scraps of cloth and bandage float in an ethereal wind, even on the calmest of days. As an action, you can speak the cloak's first command word, causing shreds of it to pull away and begin entangling a Large or smaller creature you can see within 10 feet of you. Wondrous item, rare

With safety pitchforks and protest signs strapped to the back, this plain leather satchel's unassuming exterior hides a secret within: it houses an illusory mob.

Assemble the Mob! When you open this satchel as an action, you can designate up to four willing creatures you can see within 30 feet of you to be 'multiplied' for 1 hour. Each affected creature sprouts nine illusory duplicates that all have minor alterations: different clothes, hair, and heights. The duplicates surround and follow the original and seem completely real, including sounds, smells, and temperature appropriate to the creature depicted. So long as you and any multiplied creatures remain within 100 feet of the satchel, these duplicates muddle about, shouting vaguely angry phrases such as "Get them!", "Begone!", and "Why is existence vacuous and happiness illusory!?" If a duplicated creature is ever more than 100 feet away from a satchel, its duplicates vanish.

A creature that uses its action to examine the mob can determine that it is an illusion with a successful DC 15 Intelligence (Investigation) check, ascertaining which members of the mob are real creatures.

If a creature targets a member of the mob with an attack, roll a [[/r d10]]. On a 10, it hits a real creature within the mob (GM's choice). On a 1-9, undefined. Once this property of the item has been used, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

Speckled with rust and blood, this magical saw has a wickedly keen, serrated edge. It is said to be the instrument of choice of back alley doctors and black market suppliers. Amputation operations can be conducted almost instantaneously; plenty of time before the town guard started sticking their nose in.

You have advantage on Medicine checks made to perform surgical procedures using this sword.

Amputation. When you hit a creature with this weapon, you can speak its command word, causing it to momentarily become incredibly sharp and able to cut through limbs with even a glancing blow. The target must make a DC 16 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the target takes an extra [[/r 2d12]] slashing damage and loses a randomly determined limb (use the table below). On a success, it takes half as much damage and doesn't lose a limb. Creatures with legendary resistances automatically succeed on this saving throw. Once this property has been used, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

How the creature is affected depends on the creatures' anatomy and is up to the GM's discretion. If the GM decides the creature can't be amputated, this property deals an extra [[/r 6d12]] slashing damage instead of [[/r 2d12]]. Below are examples for a humanoid.

[[/r d20]]LimbEffect
1-9LegThe target's walking speed is halved and it has disadvantage on Dexterity saving throws.
10-19ArmThe target drops whatever it is holding in this hand (if any) and has disadvantage on attack rolls using its arms. If the target has a feature or trait that allows it to make multiple attacks using its arms, it makes one fewer.
20HeadYou cut off one of the creature's heads. The creature dies if it can't survive without the lost head.

Grave's Embrace. Trailing from your back, ragged scraps of cloth and bandage float in an ethereal wind, even on the calmest of days. As an action, you can speak the cloak's first command word, causing shreds of it to pull away and begin entangling a Large or smaller creature you can see within 10 feet of you. The target must succeed on a DC 13 Strength saving throw or become restrained for 10 minutes. A creature restrained in this way takes [[/r 1d6]] necrotic damage at the start of each of its turns as it desiccates. A creature can use its action to make a DC 13 Strength check, breaking the restraints and freeing itself or another creature within its reach on a success.

Speckled with rust and blood, this magical saw has a wickedly keen, serrated edge. It is said to be the instrument of choice of back alley doctors and black market suppliers. You have advantage on Medicine checks made to perform surgical procedures using this sword.

Once this property has been used, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

Potion, rare

Doctor Jake Kill advertises his proprietary blend of bull's pituitary and caffeine as a "sure fire way to lose friends and alienate people, especially if those people are a swarm of marauding goblins." Oddly enough, he seems more than a little keen to get rid of this particular concoction...

Inner Monster. Tied up in a protective claw is a philter of bubbling red liquid. You can use an action to drink this potion, filling you with a sense of rage and selfishness as your muscles inflate and your veins bulge. You turn into a brute, the physical and mental manifestation of your most evil and selfish thoughts, for 10 minutes, and undergo the following changes:

  • Your size increases by one category and your weight is multiplied by eight.

  • You have advantage on Strength-based attack rolls, Strength checks, and Strength saving throws.

  • Your alignment changes to chaotic evil; you think of your own survival first and any trace of compassion or mercy is shredded.

When the effect ends, you return to normal and make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, you gain 1 level of exhaustion.
